metadata.title: The aerobic oxidation of bromide to dibromine catalyzed by homogeneous oxidation catalysts and initiated by nitrate in acetic acid
metadata.journal: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical

AEROBICOXIDATIONBROMIDEDIBROMINECATALYZEDBYHOMOGENEOUSOXIDATIONCATALYSTSINITIATEDBYNITRATEINACETICACID PARTENHEIMER W 1 Introduction 2 Results 2.1 Characterization of the bromide to dibromine reaction 2.2 Identifying the impurity that causes the bromide to dibromine reaction, rxn (1), to occur 2.3 Identifying the dibromine formation and coordination chemistry from the UV–vis spectra 2.4 The bromine formed is an active bromination agent 2.5 The autocatalytic nature of reaction (1) 2.6 Relative activities of transition metal/nitrate mixtures 2.7 Variables that effect the rate of the reaction 3 Discussion 3.1 Suggested mechanism of dibromine formation from Co, Mn, Br, nitrate, O2 mixtures in acetic acid 4 Experimental 4.1 MALDI-TOF-MS experiments 4.2 FT-IR experiments 4.3 UV–vis experiments APPLICATION MOLCAA 9027 S1381-1169(14)00068-5 10.1016/j.molcata.2014.02.026 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 Br K-edge EXAFS spectra, | χ ˜ ( R ) | , for a Co(a)/HBr 0.02/0.02m mixture at 25 and 95°C. Fig. 2 UV–vis spectra of 0.0193m cobalt(II) acetate tetrahydrate, with the addition of 0.0188m HBr, and after the reaction of a Co(i)/NaNO3/HBr/O2 mixture (exper. #3 in Table 1). Fig. 3 UV–vis spectra of manganese(II) acetate tetrahydrate and after the reaction of a Mn/NaNO3/HBr/O2 mixture (exper. #1 in Table 1). Fig. 4 Changes in the UV–vis spectra as a function of time for the reaction of the mixture Co(i)/Co(NO3)2/Br/O2 (exper. #21 in Table 1) during the autocatalytic changes of the reaction. The band at 650nm, due to the tetrahedral Co(II) coordination compounds, decreases and the band at 400nm, due to dibromine, increases. The times the measurements were taken, in min, are: 20.1, 27.4, 29.6, 31.1, 31.8, 32.5, 33.3, 34.0, 35.5, 45.7. Fig. 5 Exper. #21 (Table 1) as a function of time at room temperature for a Co(i)/Co(NO3)2/HBr/O2 mixture at 0.0197/0.0023/0.0188m. Squares are absorbance values at 650nm and horizontal dashes are absorbance values at 400nm. Fig. 6 Cobalt (active) as a function of temperature. The absorbance at 400nm is plotted as f(time). See exper. #30, 38 in Table 1. Table 1 Induction (IT) and reaction times (IR) of selected experiments. All concentrations in milli-molal (mm). All experiments in air at 20°C. The aerobic oxidation of bromide to dibromine catalyzed by homogeneous oxidation catalysts and initiated by nitrate in acetic acid Walter Partenheimer a ⁎ John L. Fulton b Christina M. Sorensen c Van-Thai Pham d Yongsheng Chen e a CR&D, E.I. DuPont de Nemours & Co., Inc., Experimental Station, Wilmington, DE 19880, USA CR&D, E.I. Tel.: +44 0115039777901. Graphical abstract For ∼50 years mixtures of cobalt(II) and manganese(II) acetates with sodium bromide or hydrobromic acid in acetic acid have been used as catalysts for the homogeneous aerobic oxidation of alkylaromatic compounds. They are known to be stable mixtures. While characterizing this mixture via EXAFS, it was thus surprising to observe an unexpected change in the color of the reaction mixture from deep blue to yellow or orange. Subsequent characterization of the reaction via UV–vis and EXAFS showed that the color change was due to the oxidation of bromide to dibromine. The reaction was found to require the presence of dioxygen. It was found via MALDI, IR and other methods, that the commercial source of cobalt(II) acetate contained a small amount of nitrate impurity. It is the presence of nitrate that caused the oxidation of bromide since intentional addition of various nitrate compounds causes the reaction to occur. Nitrate is likely initiating a chain reaction. The dibromine formed is an active bromination agent. Thus we show that an inexpensive, in-situ preparatory method for generating dibromine is a Mn(II) acetate/nitrate/bromide/air mixture. We show that the reaction, for T <40°C, is autocatalytic and its initiation and reaction times are dependent on a number of variables such as temperature, nitrate concentration, type of bromide and metal, pH, water concentration in acetic acid, and purity of the solvent. A cautionary note: the accidental addition of nitrate into a catalyst feed tank used for homogeneous oxidation of alkylaromatics in pilot plants or commercial plants could cause the bromide to oxidize to dibromine. This could be potentially dangerous and/or result in decreased yields. Keywords Dibromine Bromination Homogeneous oxidation catalysts Cobalt Manganese 1 Introduction Homogeneous aerobic oxidation of alkylaromatics is commercially practiced on a multi-billion lb/yr scale to produce five major products – terephthalic, isophthalic, trimellitic, pyromellitic and 2,6-dicarboxynaphthalene acids. The solvent is acetic acid with the most common metallic catalysts being the acetate salts of Co(II) and Mn(II). Addition of bromide to these metallic catalysts as HBr or NaBr, either to the individual metals or to combinations of the metals, increases their activity and selectivity during oxidation of alkylaromatic compounds. The most common catalyst is a mixture of Co/Mn/Br which gives molar yields from 80% to 95% [1]. We have been characterizing the coordination chemistry of these catalyst solutions via X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS). Previously we reported the structure of the Mn/Br catalyst in hot and supercritical water [2,3] because it had been found that aerobic oxidation of alkylaromatics was also possible in these solvents. Typically the catalyst solutions in acetic acid and acetic/water solutions are prepared and stored for extended periods of time prior to their addition to the oxidation reactors. Many years of experience (∼15yr) by one of the authors (W.P.) demonstrated that these blue solutions were stable for an indeterminate amount of time. A unexpected reaction occurred while characterizing the structure of Co/Br and Co/Mn/Br mixtures in acetic acid via EXAFS. The Co/Br mixture, consisting of Co(II) acetate and HBr, remained blue for 150min and then quickly turned to orange suggesting that some type of autocatalytic change occurred. Likewise the Co/Mn/Br mixture, consisting of Co(II) and Mn(II) acetates with HBr, also experienced an autocatalytic change from blue to orange but this occurred after an induction time of only 15min. In this paper we show that the cause of the dramatic color change was due to a nitrate impurity in the commercial cobalt(II) acetate which initiated the conversion of the HBr to dibromine (Br2) via aerobic oxidation. Oxybromination refers to bromination of an organic substrate in which the dibromine is generated in situ from hydrobromic acid or a bromide salt via an oxidant. It is a safe way of generating dibromine because transfer of the volatile dibromine from a bottle is not necessary. Peroxides, especially hydrogen peroxide, are most often used as the oxidant. Dioxygen is the preferred oxidant because of its greenness, its non-toxicity, and its ready availability in air. Because of the triplet spin state of dioxygen, 3O2, it normally does not react with HBr, NaBr, or RH because the latter exist in singlet spin states. Nevertheless, in the presence of the appropriate catalyst, dioxygen has sometimes been reported as the primary oxidant. Reported oxybromination catalysts are sodium nitrite [4], Fe, Cu, on silica/alumina [5], Cu(II) acetate [6,7], Cu(II) nitrate [8], Cu(II) bromide [9], various V, Fe, Mo compounds [10], Fe nitrate [11], and the Cu, Fe, Co phthalocyanines [12]. This work delineates the role of nitrate and the Co, Mn metals. Furthermore, we provide a variety of ways in which the rate of reaction can be enhanced, show that the reaction is autocatalytic at sufficiently low temperatures, and describe how a dangerous and/or costly situation can arise during the commercial oxidation of p-xylene if a small amount of nitrate is present in the catalyst feedtank. 2 Results 2.1 Characterization of the bromide to dibromine reaction The reaction that we discovered is (1) 4HBr+O2 →2Br2 +2H2O In addition to HBr, bromide from the salts of NaBr and LiBr was also converted to dibromine. The reaction was studied both in the presence of air, which contains 20.9% dioxygen, and under 100% dinitrogen. The reaction occurred in air but not under 100% dinitrogen. Therefore oxygen is the primary oxidant. The formation of dibromine in reaction (1) is confirmed using ultraviolet–visible spectroscopy (UV–vis) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure spectroscopy (EXAFS). As will be subsequently shown in the UV–vis spectra, a band at 400nm forms as the reaction proceeds which is consistent with the reported value for dibromine [13]. The original purpose of this research was to characterize the coordination chemistry of a hydrobromic acid/cobalt(II) acetate mixture using EXAFS at 25 and 95°C, see Fig. 1 . The plots represent the probability of finding a neighboring atom at a certain distance from the absorbing bromine atom. Fig. 1 shows the magnitude of Fourier transform, | χ ˜ ( R ) | , for two different sets of EXAFS data. Also shown are the fits to the theoretical standards (FEFF8) that were used to derive the structural parameters. The bond distances are recovered by fitting to the theoretical standards. The strong peak at 2Å is due to BrBr scattering from dibromine, whereas the peak at 2.5Å is due to the BrO bond from Br− bonding with HOAc. The latter represents bromide hydrogen bonding with acetic acid, i.e. Br−…HO(CO)CH3. The fitted parameters for the hydrobromic solution at 25°C gives a BrO bond distance of 3.12Å. For the HBr/Co(a) mixture at 95°C, reaction (1) proceeds rapidly as we see the appearance of a strong peak at 2Å which is consistent with the formation of dibromine. A small amount of hydrogen-bonded bromide with HOAc is also present, (see the absorption at 2.5Å). The fitted parameters show that at least 80% of the Br in the 95°C sample is in the form of dibromine and this dibromine has a BrBr bond distance of 2.30Å. This bond distance is very close to the literature, gas-phase value of 2.28Å. Another indication of the formation of dibromine is the positive cyclohexene tests described below. The dibromine immediately reacted when cyclohexene was added to the Co/Br solution after the color change occurred. 2.2 Identifying the impurity that causes the bromide to dibromine reaction, rxn (1), to occur We established that the active catalyst for reaction (1) was from a specific commercial source that was nominally labeled as cobalt(II) acetate tetrahydrate. We found that other commercial sources of cobalt(II) acetate tetrahydrate did not undergo reaction (1). The commercial cobalt source that catalyzes reaction (1) will be referred to as cobalt (active) (or Co(a)) and authentic samples of cobalt(II) acetate tetrahydrate, which do not catalyze the reaction, as cobalt (inactive) (or Co(i)). X-ray diffraction (XRD) established that there were significant differences between the active and inactive cobalt(II) acetate. XRD analysis also showed that the cobalt (active) consisted of mostly the dihydrate rather than the tetrahydrate. Significant differences between active and inactive cobalt(II) acetate were also observed with matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization time-of-flight mass spectroscopy (MALDI-TOF-MS) and infrared spectroscopy (IR). MALDI-TOF gave unique positive and negative ions associated with the cobalt (active) species whose molecular weights were consistent with the presence of nitrate, see Table 1S (Supplementary data). The presence of nitrate was also confirmed using EM Quant Nitrate Test Strips (10020-1) which gave positive results for cobalt (active) and negative results for cobalt (inactive). The IR of cobalt (active), cobalt (inactive) and cobalt(II) nitrate hexahydrate were compared. The IR of cobalt (active) was consistent with cobalt(II) acetate mixed with a small amount of cobalt(II) nitrate. Thus cobalt (active) contains unique absorptions at 830, 1730, and 2480cm−1 which are observed in cobalt(II) nitrate hexahydrate. This led to a series of experiments where different nitrate compounds were added to cobalt (inactive) that were found to give very similar autocatalytic changes to cobalt (active), see below. Supplementary material related to this article can be found, in the online version, at http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.molcata.2014.02.026. 2.3 Identifying the dibromine formation and coordination chemistry from the UV–vis spectra The striking color change that occurs during reaction (1) is due to both the conversion of ionic bromide to dibromine and the changes in the coordination chemistry of cobalt(II) in acetic acid. The dissolution of cobalt(II) acetate in acetic acid results in a light pink color due to the weak d–d absorptions at 530nm, see Fig. 2 . Addition of aqueous 48% HBr immediately results in an intense blue solution. The color of the solution is due to the reaction of cobalt(II) acetate to give a mixture of octahedral and tetrahedral Co(II)-bromide compounds which are in equilibrium [14,15]: (2) [ Co ( OAc ) 2 ] ( HOAc ) 4 ] + HBr Octahedral light pink color ⟶ Very fast HOAc [ Co ( Br ) 2 ( HOAc ) 2 ] Tetrahedral intense blue + [ Co ( OAc ) Br ( HOAc ) 4 ] Octahedral light pink The UV–vis spectrum of the cobalt(II) acetate/HBr mixture is given in Fig. 2. The intense absorptions at 590, 650, and 670nm are due to the presence of a small amount of the tetrahedral cobalt–bromide compounds. When sodium nitrate is added to the cobalt(II) acetate (inactive)/HBr solution, within 50min, a color change from intense blue to bright orange is observed. The UV–vis spectrum after the reaction is complete is given in Fig. 2. The absorbance at 400nm is due to dissolved dibromine. After reaction, the intense bands associated with tetrahedral cobalt(II) bromide are absent indicating that all the ionic bromide has been converted to dibromine. The spectrum after the reaction is the superposition of dibromine and cobalt(II) acetate. Thus the color change is due to the cobalt–bromide compounds being converted to Co(II) acetate and dibromine: (3) [ Co ( Br ) 2 ( HOAc ) 2 ] Tetrahedral intense blue + [ Co ( OAc ) Br ( HOAc ) 4 + O 2 Octahedral ⟶ HOAc [ Co ( OAc ) 2 ( HOAc ) 4 Octahedral light pink + H 2 O + Br 2 The absence of the tetrahedral band after the reaction suggests that the yield is essentially quantitative. For example in experiment 21, the initial absorbance at 670nm is 0.869 which reduces to 0.026 after the reaction, a decrease of 97%. UV–vis spectra were also obtained on the final product of the reaction of sodium nitrate with Mn/Br in acetic acid, see Fig. 3 . Mn(II) acetate tetrahydrate and its coordination compounds with bromide are colorless. One can again visually observe an autocatalytic reaction which eventually results in the colorless solution turning yellow. The UV–vis spectrum is identical to dibromine with a maximum at 400nm. Mn(II) could be oxidized to Mn(III) during rxn (1). Mn(III) acetate is an intense brown color with a molar absorptivity of 50 at 540nm [14]. We see no evidence for its formation in Fig. 3. 2.4 The bromine formed is an active bromination agent A classic organic test for the presence of bromine, is the addition of an olefin which reacts with the dibromine. An instantaneous color change occurred when cyclohexene was added to the above experiments after reaction (1) occurred. This was done for experiments 1, 2, 12, 16, 23 in Table 1 . The color changes are consistent with the removal of dibromine from solution upon forming the colorless dibromocyclohexane. For example, a mixture of Mn(II) acetate with sodium nitrate eventually gives a yellow solution where upon the addition of cyclohexene immediately turned the solution colorless. 2.5 The autocatalytic nature of reaction (1) The autocatalytic nature of these reactions can be illustrated from a kinetics plot that is derived from the measured UV–vis spectra (300–800nm) as a function of time, see Fig. 4 . In Fig. 5 we have plotted the absorbance as a function of time at 650nm (corresponding to the tetrahedral Co–Br species), and at 400nm (corresponding to the formation of dibromine). In Fig. 5 we see the classical features of an autocatalytic reaction. The induction time (IT) is ∼26min with a reaction time (RT) of ∼12min for a solution of Co(a)/HBr/O2 at 0.102/0.100mm. As shown in Fig. 6 , the UV–vis spectra as a function of time were also performed for cobalt (active) at 20 and 40°C. The induction time (IT) has decreased from 35 to 11min and the reaction time (RT) is reduced from 15 to 5min when the temperature was increased. Thus both the induction and reaction times have been reduced by a factor of 3. Based upon these rates, if the reaction was observed at 80°C, these times would probably be less than a minute and the autocatalytic nature of reaction (1) may not be easily detected. 2.6 Relative activities of transition metal/nitrate mixtures As explained below, the induction and reaction times are very sensitive to the purity of the acetic acid and hence only experiments with the same purity of solvent can be compared. Solvent 1 is Aldrich acetic acid with 99.99+% purity and solvent 2 is Aldrich acetic acid with 99.7+% purity. Slower induction times are observed in solvent 1. With the lower purity solvent longer induction times are observed in the order Mn/Br/NO3 − <Co/Mn/Br/NO3 − <Co/Br/NO3 − <Co/Ce/Br/NO3 − <Ce/Br/NO3 − for experiments using Co(i) (experiments 1–5 in Table 1). In higher purity solvent #1, using Co(a), it is found that the IT's are Co/Mn/Br<Co/Br (experiments 6 and 7). Mn/Br, activated with HNO3 was more active than Co(a)/Mn/Br and Co(a)/Br (experiment 8 versus experiments 6 and 7). We conclude that manganese(II) acetate has the strongest catalytic activity for rxn (1), i.e. has the shortest induction times. We further determined that nitrate salts without transition metals were also active in promoting the conversion of bromide salts to dibromine. Mixures of NaNO3/HBr, HNO3/LiBr, NaNO3/LiBr, and NaNO3/NaBr all result in colorless solutions that eventually turn yellow, see experiments 9–13 (Table 1). However, transition metal/nitrate mixtures were considerably more active having faster IT and RT's at the same nitrate concentration. Thus the mixtures containing Co and Mn, were much more active, despite in some cases having considerable lower nitrate concentrations (experiments 1–3 and 14–17 versus 9–13). In contrast, the Ce containing catalysts (exper. 4, 5, 18) are the least active having similar IT and RT's as the non-metal containing catalysts. 2.7 Variables that effect the rate of the reaction Solvent purity. We initially used two bottles of acetic acid with Aldrich catalog number 33,882-6 with 99.99+% purity based on metals analysis. Then a less pure bottle, Aldrich catalog number 24,285-3, 99.7+% reagent grade purity was used to conclude the experiments. In four cases where identical experiments are compared, the higher purity acetic acid gave longer IT and RT's than those with lower purity. The higher purity acetic acid is dubbed “solvent #1” in Table 1 and the lower purity as “solvent #2”. For example, when cobalt (active) was reacted with HBr with solvent 1, the IT and RT was 143min and 29min, respectively. In contrast when using solvent #2, the IT and RT were 60 and 17min, i.e. these were 2.4 times and 1.7 times faster than with the more pure solvent (compare experiments 7 and 20, Table 1). Similarly, with a Co(i)/Co(NO3)2/HBr/O2 mixture (compare experiments 17, 21, and 22), at similar nitrate concentrations, the IT and RT's were faster in solvent #2. We did not further explore why these two solvents gave such different results. Solvent 1 probably has significantly less impurity metal concentrations. It is well known that the presence of small amounts of impurity metals, such as copper and vanadium, affect the activity and selectivity in the autoxidation of hydrocarbons using a Co/Mn/Br catalyst [1]. Nitrate source. Three different sources of nitrate, cobalt(II) nitrate, sodium nitrate, and nitric acid, when added to metals all resulted in dibromine formation (rxn #1), see Table 1. Activity as a function of nitrate concentration. In general the activity for a given mixture increases with increasing nitrate concentration. For example, one can compare experiments 25, 22, 26 where the IT decreases from 213 to 183 to 141min and the RT decreases from >77 to 34 to 14min when the nitrate concentration increases from 0.0025 to 0.0038 to 0.021m. Bromide source. Three different sources of bromide were used in these experiments, HBr, NaBr, and LiBr, all which were active in producing dibromine, see Table 1. Effect of water concentration. With no water added, the Co(a)/Mn/HBr/O2 mixture has a IT of 27min and RT of 31min (experiment 27). In a 4.6wt% water/HOAc mixture, reaction (1) occurred between 96 and 976min hence the IT is longer (exper. 28). With 10.1wt% water/HOAc there was no reaction up to 1740min (exper. 29). We conclude that water inhibits reaction (1). Water is a product in reaction (1) and additional water is added via the metals since they were added as their acetate hydrates. However, the contribution of water due to reaction (1) and the metal hydrates is only ∼0.2wt% hence there is probably very little inhibition from these sources. Variation of carboxylic solvent. The reaction mixture of cobalt(II) acetate (active) and HBr in acetic acid turned an orange color at 50min (visually measured) or 35min (measured by UV–vis) see experiment 30. Reaction (1) was also observed in a Co(a)/HBr/O2 mixture in propionic acid. The initiation time was between 22 and 66min which is similar to that in acetic acid, see experiment 19. Thus the type of carboxylic acid solvent had little effect on the reaction. Effect of pH. In water, an increase in pH is determined by the increase in the hydroxyl concentration since the dissociation reaction is 2H2O⇌2H+ +2OH− In acetic acid the dissociation reaction is 2HOAc⇌2H+ +2OAc− hence an increase in pH is determined by an increase in the acetate concentration. We found that addition of approximately an equal molar amount of ammonium acetate, a base, to Co (active) increased the induction time from 60 to 106min and increased the reaction time from 17 to 49min, (experiments 20 and 31). With four times as much ammonium acetate added, no reaction was observed (experiment 32). Thus increasing the pH is detrimental to the reaction. The effect of pH can also be seen in a Co(a)/Mn(OAc)2 mixture by comparing HBr and NaBr as the bromide source. The induction time and the reaction time both were longer when HBr was used, (experiment 33 compared to 6 and 27). When a fivefold excess of HBr is added to a Co (active)/Mn/Br no reaction is observed, (experiment 34). Thus too low a pH is detrimental to the reaction. This suggests that a pH either too high or too low detrimentally affects the rate of reaction, i.e. there is an optimum pH that must be used to observe reaction (1). Effect of halogen type. While a Co(a)/Mn/HBr/O2 mixture undergoes reaction (1) within 30min, a Co(a)/Mn/HCl/O2 mixture did not react for >1350min so we conclude that this system is not able to catalyze the conversion of chloride to dichlorine (experiments 35 versus 27). Effect of bromine/metals ratio. Most of the experiments were at a bromine/metals of ∼1.0. Higher ratios can be obtained if the pH is kept relatively constant. Thus reaction (1) did occur with a Br/metals ratio of 3.8mol/mol, using LiBr as the bromide source (exper. 36). Effect of Mn/Co ratio. Changing the Mn/Co ratio from 1.3 to 0.26mol/mol using a Co(a)/Mn/HBr/O2 mixture resulted in a slightly shorter induction time (31–24min) and a faster reaction time (57min compared to 12min) (see experiments 6 and 37). Effect of the presense of light. An active mixture was prepared using cobalt(II) acetate (inactive)/cobalt(II) nitrate/HBr and immediately wrapped in aluminum foil. Seven hours later the aluminum foil was removed and the solution was an orange color, i.e. reaction (1) had occurred in the dark. 3 Discussion Bromination is a very common organic reaction. It is much safer to generate the dibromine in situ than adding it from a bottle of dibromine [16] since dibromine is quite volatile and toxic. The use of a Mn/Br mixture in acetic acid with a small amount of nitrate to generate the dibromine in acetic acid would be a convenient way to generate the dibromine since this mixture has a very short induction and reaction time at room temperature. It is possible that the presence of the nitrate could result in some nitration of the ring. This discovery of a catalyst solution of Co/Br and Co/Mn/Br, in the presence of a small amount of nitrate, that aerobically oxidizes the bromide to dibromine has practical, and dangerous consequences since dibromine is a volatile, gaseous, suffocating, corrosive and toxic substance. In our studies, we used only ∼5g solutions, so only minute amounts of dibromine formed. However, if we were preparing a catalyst solution for the aerobic oxidation of p-xylene in a pilot plant, or a commercial plant much larger volumes would be used. Therefore, if a small amount of nitrate were present in the catalyst feed tank, reaction (1) could occur. The solubility of dioxygen in acetic acid is 0.008M at 293K and 1bar pressure. Thus, approximately 0.016 moles of Br2 would form per liter of liquid that would be equivalent to ∼0.41l of gaseous dibromine at standard conditions. If an operator happened to extract a sample from the feed tank, he might be exposed to a very large amount of dibromine. Furthermore, the volatile dibromine would enter the vapor space in the catalyst feed tank potentially resulting in a reduced bromine/metals ratio in the oxidation reactor. This would decrease the aromatic acid yield and increase undesirable side-products such as carbon dioxide – a greenhouse gas. The manufacture of terephthalic acid is a continuous process with very stringent quality controls. A sudden lowering of the terephthalic acid yield even by 1mol%, would disrupt the entire plant and consequently be very costly. 3.1 Suggested mechanism of dibromine formation from Co, Mn, Br, nitrate, O2 mixtures in acetic acid We have the following four types of evidence that nitrate is not a stoichiometric oxidant of bromide and hence is probably initiating the chain reaction. (1) If nitrate is a stoichiometric oxidant supplying five electron equivalents and assuming all five equivalents were used, then Br/nitrate ratios greater than five would result in an incomplete reaction. We find, however, in Table 1 that Br/nitrate ratios greater than five still gave essentially quantitative yields (see experiments 22, 23, 24, and 25). (2) We have also performed the EM semiquantitative nitrate tests after rxn (1) has been completed and we found that all gave positive nitrate tests after rxn (1) (experiments 23, 24, 26, 38, and 39) with the remaining nitrate not much different than the initial nitrate present. Thus little of the nitrate has reacted. (3) One can roughly estimate the amount of nitrate in cobalt (active), using the semiquantitative nitrate test, as being between 4.5 and 9.0wt%. This would give a bromine/nitrate ratio of 7.5 in samples 28 and 29 in Table 1 which is insufficient to complete the reaction. (4) We have observed on three occasions that the presence of dioxygen (air) was necessary for the reaction to occur. Therefore, dioxygen is at least one of the oxidants. The autocatalytic nature of the reaction is consistent with a free radical chain mechanism. Nitrate is a strong oxidant and is known to react through free radical mechanisms [17]. We have observed that a solution of Co/Mn/nitrate/O2 (no bromide present) in acetic acid does change slowly to a brown solution within 7h at room temperature. Mn(III) has a dark brown color hence this suggests that a species originating from nitrate oxidized the Mn(II) to Mn(III). The chemistry of nitrate as an oxidant is very complex as many species form such as N2O, NO, N2O3, NO2, N2O4, and N2O5. For instance, dinitrogen trioxide is dark blue and nitrogen dioxide is brown. We did not observe colored gases evolving from our different solutions which is consistent with only a small amount of the nitrate oxidizing the bromide. We have discussed above a variety of variables that affect the reaction and induction times of rxn (1). The variables that affect the activity and selectivity of the Co/Mn/Br catalyzed oxidation of p-xylene are similar. The observations that they have in common are (1) NaBr reacts at the different rate than HBr, (2) the rates are dependent upon pH, (3) HCl does not react, (4) the reaction is inhibited by water, (5) addition of excess acid (HBr) prohibits the reaction, (6) the reaction occurs in both acetic acid and propionic acid, and (7) the steady-state concentration of Mn(III) is extremely low [1,13]. The chemistry of nitrate, bromide, and dioxygen is complex therefore many different mechanisms could be postulated. Also a variety of oxides of bromine can form in the +1, +3, +4, +5, +7 oxidation states [18]. Because of the similarity of observations made in this paper for Co/Mn/Br/NO3 −1 to those made during the Co/Mn/Br catalyzed oxidation of p-xylene, we will present a mechanism similar to that observed in p-xylene oxidation [1]: 1. Initiation. One possibility is the reaction of nitrate with bromide to give the bromine atom radical (Br*): (4) HNO3 +HBr→Br +NO2 +H2O 2. Propagation (5) Br +O2 →BrO2 (6) BrO2 +HBr→HOO +Br2 (7) HOO +HBr→BrO +H2O (8) BrO +HBr→HOBr+Br (9) HOBr+HBr→H2O+Br2 The sum of the five propagation steps above is rxn (1): (1) 4HBr+O2 →2Br2 +2H2O In the presence of Co and Mn, we find experimentally that the induction time is greatly reduced and significantly less nitrate is required for the reaction to occur. This can be rationalized by reactions (10) and (11): (10) [M(II)-Br]2 +2HNO3 +2H+ →[M(III)-Br]2 +2NO2 +2H2O M=Co(II), Mn(II) (other ligands are acetate, acetic acid, and water [19]). It is known that most of the bromide in anhydrous acetic acid is coordinated to the metals [19], that the geometry of the ligands is mostly octahedral [19], that Co(II) is dimeric in acetic acid [20,21] and that both Co(III) and Mn(III) can oxidize bromide to the bromine atom. So the metal can then act as an initiator, just as nitrate does in rxn (4): (11) [M(III)-Br]2 →[M(II)M(III)Br]2 +Br It is known that reaction (11) is faster for Mn(II) than Co(II) which is consistent with Mn being more active than Co in generating dibromine. Alternatively, rxn (11) could generate dibromine in one concerted step assuming Mn is a dimer in solution (the same as Co(II) is) (12) [M(III)-Br]2 →[M(II)]2 +Br2 So the dibromine could be generated directly from the metals, rxn (12) as well as from the free radical chain mechanism, rxns (4)–(9). The retardation in rate due to the presence of water in acetic acid can be explained by Eqs. (11) and (12) since it is known that less bromide is coordinated to the metals with increasing water content in acetic acid [19]. The strong catalytic effect of Co and Mn in promoting reaction (1) and the lack of such an effect by Ce(IV) is consistent with the fact that Co and Mn are frequently used homogeneous oxidation catalysts and Ce is only occasionally used [1,22]. The strong promoting effect of bromide in homogeneous oxidation is due to the ability of Co and Mn to rapidly undergo reactions (11) and (12) [20]. This is consistent with Co and Mn promoting the bromide to dibromine reaction in which now reaction (11) initiates and reaction (12) produces dibromine directly from bromide. 4 Experimental All experiments were performed in 10 cc vials containing ∼5g solvent. The amounts of all reagents and solvent were weighed out on an analytical balance to 0.0001g. Weight of the reagents was generally between 0.005 and 0.03g. Because such small amounts were used, the target weights in duplicate experiments varied from 0.5% to 5%. All of the reagents stated below were used as received. Cobalt (active) was a specific lot of Aldrich cobalt(II) acetate tetrahydrate with 99.999% purity (metals basis). Cobalt (inactive) was Aldrich reagent grade cobalt(II) acetate tetrahydrate. Two different sources of hydrobromic acid were compared – Alpha (99.9999% metals purity) and Alpha ACS reagent grade. Two differences sources of acetic acid were compared – Aldrich (99.99% metals basis) and Aldrich reagent grade. Aldrich anhydrous cobalt(II) acetate, Aldrich cobalt(II) oxide, Alfa Aesar ACS grade sodium nitrate, Alfa Aesar puritronic cobalt(II) nitrate hexahydrate, Aldrich 70wt% nitric acid, Sigma–Aldrich reagent grade lithium bromide, Sigma >99.5% purity sodium bromide, Sigma–Aldrich reagent grade cyclohexene, Sigma–Aldrich ACS reagent propionic acid were also used as received. 4.1 MALDI-TOF-MS experiments A Bruker Autoflex II MALDI-TOF-MS was operated in reflectron mode following external calibration with peptide standards in alpha cyano cinnaminic acid with a mass range covering 100–2500 m/z. Samples (5mg) of the active and inactive Co(II) acetate tetrahydrate were suspended in 500μl milli-Q water, methanol, or acetic acid and deposited in multiple layers directly onto a stainless steel plate. Initial deposition using typical organic matrices (dithranol, alpha cyano cinnaminic acid) was complex and not informative. Identification was based on the mass assignment match to the expected m/z matching the theoretical m/z within 100ppm mass error. Data was collected in positive and negative ion mode. 4.2 FT-IR experiments IR spectra were acquired using a Bruker IFS-66V FTIR spectrophotometer with an liquid nitrogen cooled MCT detector. The solid samples were prepared by dissolution in acetic acid and then placing a drop onto a thin-film polyethylene IR transmission card. The acetic acid was allowed to evaporate to dryness using house nitrogen. As a further measure, the samples were run under vacuum in the evacuated sample compartment of the spectrometer to eliminate contributions from volatile components. 4.3 UV–vis experiments UV–vis absorption measurements were performed using a Shimadzu spectrometer UV-2401PC. The spectrometer was operated in repeat scan mode wherein the reaction kinetics were measured by a series of consecutive spectra. During kinetics measurements, a spectrum with wavelength range 300–800nm (scanning interval 2nm) was acquired in about 45s. High temperature measurements were carried out using a hot water circulator (VWR Model 1146) coupled directly to a special cuvette holder. 4.4 EXAFS experiments The Br K-edge (13474eV) EXAFS spectra were collected in transmission mode on a bending magnet beamline at the Pacific Northwest Consortium/X-ray Science Division (PNC/XSD) bending-magnet beamline at Sector 20 of the Advanced Photon Source (APS) at Argonne National Laboratory (ANL). The details of the methods have been previously described [2,3]. Briefly, for the Br K-edge measurements a small liquid cell constructed from titanium having an internal volume of about 2mL was used. Two 0.5mm thick, PEEK windows were used for X-ray transmission and to provide a pathlength of about 1cm. Typically three 15min spectra were co-added. PNC/XSD facilities at the Advanced Photon Source, and research at these facilities, are supported by the US Department of Energy – Basic Energy Sciences, the Canadian Light Source and its funding partners, the University of Washington, and the Advanced Photon Source. Use of the Advanced Photon Source, an Office of Science User Facility operated for the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) Office of Science by Argonne National Laboratory, was supported by the U.S. DOE under Contract No. DE-AC02-06CH11357. coredata.dc:description: For ∼50 years mixtures of cobalt(II) and manganese(II) acetates with sodium bromide or hydrobromic acid in acetic acid have been used as catalysts for the homogeneous aerobic oxidation of alkylaromatic compounds. They are known to be stable mixtures. While characterizing this mixture via EXAFS, it was thus surprising to observe an unexpected change in the color of the reaction mixture from deep blue to yellow or orange. Subsequent characterization of the reaction via UV–vis and EXAFS showed that the color change was due to the oxidation of bromide to dibromine. The reaction was found to require the presence of dioxygen. It was found via MALDI, IR and other methods, that the commercial source of cobalt(II) acetate contained a small amount of nitrate impurity. It is the presence of nitrate that caused the oxidation of bromide since intentional addition of various nitrate compounds causes the reaction to occur. Nitrate is likely initiating a chain reaction. The dibromine formed is an active bromination agent. Thus we show that an inexpensive, in-situ preparatory method for generating dibromine is a Mn(II) acetate/nitrate/bromide/air mixture. We show that the reaction, for T <40°C, is autocatalytic and its initiation and reaction times are dependent on a number of variables such as temperature, nitrate concentration, type of bromide and metal, pH, water concentration in acetic acid, and purity of the solvent. A cautionary note: the accidental addition of nitrate into a catalyst feed tank used for homogeneous oxidation of alkylaromatics in pilot plants or commercial plants could cause the bromide to oxidize to dibromine. This could be potentially dangerous and/or result in decreased yields.

coredata.dc:title: The aerobic oxidation of bromide to dibromine catalyzed by homogeneous oxidation catalysts and initiated by nitrate in acetic acid
